item.title: 4 stars (Mojo)
item.dc:creator: kim
item.description: True record-geekdom means championing music that no one else likes or even knows. It’s easy to pour on the irony in gushing about some chintzy garage-sale find, but what makes Lost in the Grooves a really groovy read is the honest passion its contributors exhibit for their lost-and-found faves. Doug Harvey tells of accidentally buying … Continue reading "4 stars (Mojo)"
item.content:encoded: True record-geekdom means championing music that no one else likes or even knows. It’s easy to pour on the irony in gushing about some chintzy garage-sale find, but what makes Lost in the Grooves a really groovy read is the honest passion its contributors exhibit for their lost-and-found faves. Doug Harvey tells of accidentally buying Yoko Ono’s Plastic Ono Band thinking it was Lennon’s same-titled LP, and growing to love it. Others rave about deserving MIAs, from Harry ‘The Hipster’ Gibson and Buckner & Garcia to Sylvester and The Loud Family. Can we please draw the line at Aaron Carter though? (Jeff Tamarkin, Mojo, 4/5 Stars)
